abstract: The Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years, but if Exxon Mobil’s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over.
snippet: The Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years, but if Exxon Mobil’s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over.
lead_paragraph: The gas-rich land of the Marcellus shale has offered some of the hottest wildcat real estate in recent years. But if Exxon Mobil’s recent $1.7 billion acquisition is any indication, the days of eye-watering prices are over. The oil titan is paying barely half the price such acres were fetching last year, as the frenzy has shifted to Texas. Cheaper real estate may even make gas assets look appealing again.

headline.main: Prices Fall for Some Gas-Rich Shale Land

byline.original: By Christopher Swann and Reynolds Holding
